messageBody:
Hi Joakim,

--- Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...> wrote:

> If testing private methods is what you´re really
> after I would consider:

Well - I would categorize it more as testing methods
period. I just want them tested with minimum effort
required to test them, while keeping the tests tightly
linked with the build process, so that the tests are
always testing what will run in production.

> a) as already mentioned by others, see if there is
> some way you can
> structure your code so that you can implicitly test
> whats private with
> little effort.
>As has already been suggested your
> *Helper may want to
> have different names, some may want to be merged,
> some broken up. And
> according to my taste stop being static and then
> injected to the class
> you want to test.

I usually inject the *Class, but the *ClassHelper has
all static methods. It's methods receive all
arguments from the *Class. It's a "Private" utility
library so to speak. Only the *Class stores state.


>
> A lot of good stuff can be found here:
>
http://www.objectmentor.com/resources/publishedArticles.html
> (click on by topic | design)
>

Thanks for the link. I'll have a look.

> I would start looking at the single responsibility
> principle. That is
> in my experience the principle that had the biggest
> impact on my
> unit-testing (together with the depenency inversion
> principle).


Yes - I think Dependency Injection rocks. I also like
separation of concerns and single responsibility. A
few of the reasons I like Class + ClassHelper is that
ClassHelper is unique to Class, and ClassHelper
methods can be easily moved to a utility library
later, with a minimum amount of refactoring, along
with the corresponding tests. It also keeps Class
very clean and focused. When I look at Class, I see
precisely what it does, without a lot of clutter. It
stores state, and has a few methods that are focused
on it's core concern/responsibility/role.




>
> b) consider making them package-private or default
> if you prefer to
> call it that (remove the private, protected, public
> modifier
> entirely). This is just above private, these methods
> are only
> accessible by other classes in the same package. Not
> even subclasses
> can access them if they are in a different package
> (there is a common
> misunderstanding that default less restricted than
> protected, it's
> really the other way around.

Thanks for the review :-) I think it would be great
to have cheat sheet for that one :-)

I like to have my tests in separate packages
sometimes, and sometimes in separate projects, so that
makes it a little trickier.

>
> c) perform securitymanager stunts to acces the
> actual private methods.
> I would consider this a bit paranoid.
>

Yeah - I think even if the the private / protected /
default access constraints could could be turned off
in the JVM for testing, I may still stick with Class +
ClassHelper for reasons I specify at the end.

> I look at both b) and c) as workarounds. Sometimes
> we need workarounds
> until we figure out how everything should fit.
>
> Of course, if you are comfortable with the helper
> style, by all means
> continue with that. From where I'm standing it looks
> like it is the
> design part of TDD that wants to be listened to. I
> am standing quite
> far away though so I may be wrong.

I think you hit the nail on the head :-)

I think designs that result from test driven
development are clean, simple, and easy to work with
and improve.

The tests are also a great source of documentation.

I also prefer to minimize the amount of code in the
"Core Project" and utilize utility libraries as much
as possible. This means less documentation effort and
more utility libraries for everyone to use. Less
coding too.

So I try to move methods to utilities as much as
possible. Using the Helper makes it easy for myself
and others to do this, when working in teams. Also,
the overhead of wondering "How should we structure
this so we can test everything" is eliminated. We
just say

Class + Helper :-)

Cheers,
- Ole
